instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6905: What is C6905? Capacitor to ground on charger input, if this shorts to ground the charger will not put out any power. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> measured at PAD 1 F6905 is 0V

Diode mode
F6905: 0V on both pads (shorted)
<RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>: shorted on both sides

<RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>: 47 Ohms

? Short somewhere on the <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> rail

I remember the warning not to inject voltage ever into anything that supplies <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unless high side mosfets are checked first.

How do you begin to isolate a short on a rail with so many points where the short could be?

Start checking voltages at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Are you sure about that short?
Did you disconnect charger on measured on diode mode?

Did you try known good DCIN board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Why do you like so much to measure same line in various points???
One value is sufficient; unless the trace is broken.

Looks like you have a short inside copper layers.
No cap, or active component remains directly connected to ground on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> line.

Just in case, remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
you think the short is in the board itself?
i.e. not fixable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Sometime possible.
You must cuttoff that line in few points.
The idea is to isolate the short part and bypass it with an wire.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> removed

Still short to ground tested at <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> PIN 1

When F6905 removed
PIN 1: OL
PIN 2: SHORT

So short is after F6905 (not in dc in board or J6900) and Not in <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> or in reverse current protection part of circuit?

Remove <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and check if short remains on PIN 1 or PIN 2?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
How can a resistor (high ohm value) generate a short???

I faced with similar problem years ago, with old 2879 board; solved with method above mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Here is my logic:

As you said, I have to cut off the <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at various points, I chose <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>

Remove <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and check if short remains on PIN 1 or PIN 2?

If <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> is removed AND


PIN 2 Diode mode to ground is SHORT then the short is somewhere in the line after that resistor

I know my logic must be screwed up somehow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
That logic has NO sense at all.

You actually don't and never will have short on pin 2/<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>.
If you have short on pin 1 (0 ohm), how can 0+30K generate that short???

Please understand, the goal of this forum is to help online on the repair process.
If you need training course, contact Rossmann's staff.

Follow <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> trace and cutt it off in few points.
Not close to any component terminal; just in the middle of some of its sections.
Post pictures of what you did.
And specify, where the short remained.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
[U][I]Follow <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> trace and cutt it off in few points.[/I][/U]

By "cut it off" do you mean actually disrupt the trace by breaking the physical copper trace on the board ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message: Exactlly, perfectly understood; just do it now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
And I will may need more than 1 break in the trace potentially to ?jump? the short
?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
Of course, you need to isolate the trace part shorted to ground.
At least two points to cuttoff <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
You'll probably need to do it in more points, untill find the way to isolate the short.

First of all, try to isolate <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> input.
This MOSFET must be soldered in its place.
The other components can be soldered in just one pin and run a wire to a common point for the other pin of them all; including F6905.

Now no short at PIN 1
Short at PIN 4

Short somewhere in DC sense in circuit?

<TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR> PIN 2 is also short to ground

Will continue to test

leave it? Are you joking?
Come on
i posted correct info now

I cut traces, you explained that to me. I did it correctly
i moved to isolate it and I found a problem at <TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR>
That trace leading to pad 4 should not be short
I thought that was the f**ging short that I found

now I want to know if that is correct and how to proceed
am I wrong about this trace now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light on Magsafe
threads.message:
How can <TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR> generate the short, if has NO other pin connected to ground (apart of pin 1)???
Your problem is inside board, between copper layers.

You didn't separate <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> in sufficient points.
And probably will not even be possible; that's the reason I said "leave it"...
